intro: Notothlaspi hookeri, commonly known as Hooker's whitlow grass, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important plants such as cabbages and mustards. The plant is characterized by its basal rosette of narrow, silver-haired leaves and small white or pale yellow flowers arranged in a raceme. It thrives in rocky and arid environments, showcasing adaptations to harsh climatic conditions. Notothlaspi hookeri is often found in alpine meadows and is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological niche.
